articles.headline: Intel, in Show of Support for Trump, Announces Factory in Arizona
articles.snippet: The world’s largest chip manufacturer, which opposes President Trump’s immigration order but backs his tax and regulatory plans, will invest $7 billion to finish a factory conceived in 2011.
articles.abstract: The world’s largest chip manufacturer, which opposes President Trump’s immigration order but backs his tax and regulatory plans, will invest $7 billion to finish a factory conceived in 2011.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel, the world’s largest computer chip manufacturer, will invest $7 billion to finish a factory in Arizona, adding 3,000 jobs, the company’s chief executive said on Wednesday after meeting with President Trump at the White House.

articles.headline: Jeff Sessions Confirmed as Attorney General, Capping Bitter Battle
articles.snippet: The Alabama senator survived a near-party-line vote after a racially charged nomination battle that crested with the procedural silencing of Senator Elizabeth Warren.
articles.abstract: The Alabama senator survived a near-party-line vote after a racially charged nomination battle that crested with the procedural silencing of Senator Elizabeth Warren.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Jeff Sessions was confirmed on Wednesday as President Trump’s attorney general, capping a bitter and racially charged nomination battle that crested with the procedural silencing of a leading Democrat, Senator Elizabeth Warren.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Worries Grow Over Euro’s Fate as Debts Smolder in Italy and Greece
articles.snippet: Even as global stock markets climb, concerns are building that debt problems in Greece and Italy will put additional strain on the euro.
articles.abstract: Even as global stock markets climb, concerns are building that debt problems in Greece and Italy will put additional strain on the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as global stock markets climb, worries are building among investors that long-simmering debt troubles in Greece and Italy will put additional strain on the euro.

articles.headline: Battle to Retake Syrian City Turns Into a Geopolitical Test of the War
articles.snippet: A race is on to reclaim Al Bab from Islamic State extremists. Whether the rival forces ringing the city will cooperate or kill one another is unclear.
articles.abstract: A race is on to reclaim Al Bab from Islamic State extremists. Whether the rival forces ringing the city will cooperate or kill one another is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A northern Syrian city that is one of the Islamic State’s last enclaves in the country is under assault by military forces bearing down from all sides.

articles.headline: Letters From Jacqueline Kennedy to the Man She Didn’t Marry
articles.snippet: Newly discovered letters from Mrs. Kennedy to Lord Harlech, whose heart she broke, explain her decision to marry Aristotle Onassis.
articles.abstract: Newly discovered letters from Mrs. Kennedy to Lord Harlech, whose heart she broke, explain her decision to marry Aristotle Onassis.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In November 1967, four years after her husband’s assassination, Jacqueline Kennedy traveled to the temples of Angkor Wat in Cambodia on a much-publicized trip with David Ormsby Gore, a friend of her husband and himself a recent widower.

articles.headline: Lionsgate’s Bets Pay Off as Studio Makes a Big Comeback
articles.snippet: Lionsgate’s films, including “La La Land” and “Hacksaw Ridge,” received 26 Oscar nominations, and the company reported strong earnings on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Lionsgate’s films, including “La La Land” and “Hacksaw Ridge,” received 26 Oscar nominations, and the company reported strong earnings on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — In July, Lionsgate was stuck under a storm cloud.

articles.headline: Trump Wants More American Cars in Japan. Japan’s Drivers Don’t.
articles.snippet: Even Japanese fans of cars from the United States point to company missteps that make American vehicles unappealing there.
articles.abstract: Even Japanese fans of cars from the United States point to company missteps that make American vehicles unappealing there.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Yoshihiro Masui’s growling Ford hot-rod, its sides adorned with the Stars and Stripes, attests to his love of American cars — an unusual passion in Japan, where Toyota, Honda and other domestic brands rule the roads.

articles.headline: Trump Tells Xi Jinping U.S. Will Honor ‘One China’ Policy
articles.snippet: President Trump and Mr. Xi, the Chinese leader, spoke by phone on Thursday evening after an extended chill in the two countries’ relationship.
articles.abstract: President Trump and Mr. Xi, the Chinese leader, spoke by phone on Thursday evening after an extended chill in the two countries’ relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump told President Xi Jinping of China on Thursday evening that the United States would honor the “One China” policy, reversing his earlier expressions of doubt about the longtime diplomatic understanding and removing a major source of tension between the United States and China since shortly after he was elected.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Michael Forsythe
